title: FIX README.md
body: I just updated README.md to the working syntax.

title: initial setup for dev suggestions
body:
In this PR I've made some contributions:

- Added `poetry` as the dependency manager
- Added `pre-commit` and `black` hooks formatter
- Applied the `black` formatter on the entire project.

All code changes are style-related.

title: added dependencies and custom exceptions
body:
# Proposed changes

- Added `isort` to `pre-commit` and as a dev dependency
- Added `openai` to dependencies.
- Apply `isort` to the entire project (purely style).
- Added a custom exception to API Key Not Found error.

title: Error Correcting Framework
body:
A couple of Changes:
1. Changed the signature of giving the prompt to LLM. Have asked it to return the Python code surrounded by "startCode" and "endCode". Found out by experimenting that the LLM is good at giving the output in this format and it becomes easy to extract the required code.
2. Added Error Correcting Framework With Max Retry of 3.

If show_code is set to True, it will create a new cell and paste the code that was used to generate the answer.

This one:

title: feat: expose REST/Websocket APIs using langchain-serve
body:
## pandas-ai ü§ù [langchain-serve](https://github.com/jina-ai/langchain-serve)


This PR adds a ton of features targeting to push `pandas-ai` production-readiness üöÄ (Fixes #21)

- Enables interacting with pandas-ai as REST/WebSocket APIs using langchain-serve.
- Introduces `pandas-ai` CLI with the following options üëâ [Documentation](https://github.com/deepankarm/pandas-ai#pandas-ai-cli-experimental)
   - Expose APIs locally
   - Expose APIs on Jina AI Cloud
   - Upload DataFrames to Jina AI Cloud
   - Converse playground to have real-time question/answers about dataframes both on local & on cloud
 
## Demo for converse playground
![converse](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9050737/236296259-be2163d8-9b25-46f2-8f54-d3d7e1cc9bfe.gif)


### Known limitations 
- Plotting graphs is not supported via the API yet.
- Upload/Download of DataFrames is currently done using CSVs. More formats will be supported in the future.
- Missing tests for the new APIs (to be added in the next PR)

title: security
body: This PR adds improvements to the LLM-generated code execution code in Python. Added type checking and type conversion capabilities, as well as restricting access to modules and functions deemed unsafe through the use of Python's ast library. In addition, unit tests were performed to ensure the correct functioning of the code. These improvements are expected to increase the security and robustness of code generated by LLM in Python.

title: Anonymized data frame head
body:
The main goal of this PR is to anonymize a few data (like email, phone numbers and credit cards) and shuffle the non-sensitive data. 

The reason behind it is that we're sending a data frame head to a remote LLM (like OpenAI GPT) and we want to be sure that the info cannot be used by anyone in an unwanted way.

title: added support to oobabooga/text-generation-webui - fixed base.py to return error when "no_code"
body:
Added support to `oobabooga/text-generation-webui` through API.

You can test starting text-generation-webui with:
`python server.py --api --listen --no-stream --model-menu` 

and the following code:

```import pandas as pd
from pandasai import PandasAI

# Sample DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame({
    "country": ["United States", "United Kingdom", "France", "Germany", "Italy", "Spain", "Canada", "Australia", "Japan", "China"],
    "gdp": [19294482071552, 2891615567872, 2411255037952, 3435817336832, 1745433788416, 1181205135360, 1607402389504, 1490967855104, 4380756541440, 14631844184064],
    "happiness_index": [6.94, 7.16, 6.66, 7.07, 6.38, 6.4, 7.23, 7.22, 5.87, 5.12]
})

from pandasai.llm.text_gen_webui import TextGenWebuiLLM
llm = TextGenWebuiLLM()
pandas_ai = PandasAI(llm, verbose=True)
pandas_ai.run(df, prompt='Which are the 5 happiest countries?')
```

title: possible solution to the security problem using `exec`
body: The following pull request has a possible solution to the security problem using `exec`, mainly it adds a global vars dictionary and passes it to the exec function so exec's scope is limited to the variables and built-in functions defined in the dictionary.

The branch name in the `.pylintrc` file was `MASTER`, that's why the linting in tests was not ignored. 

And I took this opportunity to move the `.pylintrc` config to `pyproject.toml`.

title: Add ChatGPT based on IntelligenzaArtificiale/Free-AUTO-GPT-with-NO-API
body:
How to use it:
`llm = ChatGPT(conversation_id="CHAT_ID", api_token="CHATGPT_API_TOKEN")`

conversation_id is the id on the chat url.
CHATGPT_API_TOKEN can be found on the chatgpt cookies, with the name: __Secure-next-auth.session-token

---

use it at your own risk.

For the best user experience, I have set the default output of pandasai to be verbose and made sure to implement various error checks that print out only a single line detailing what went wrong.

title: Support for Azure Openai
body:
Hello,
this PR aims at integrating Azure OpenAI API into pandasAI, addressing #96 .

I went for separate implementation instead of adding the required changes to `openai.py` for the following two reasons:
- keeping the latter cleaner, avoiding ambiguities between the model, the engine and the additional params Azure requires, which would be all ignored in the "classical" OpenAI version
- it's not so straightforward in Azure OpenAI to extract the model name from the deployment name and to associate it to a completion or a chat model

title: Update constants.py
body:
Add comments to explain the purpose and usage of the constants.

Use snake_case for the variable names instead of camelCase for consistency.

Use tuples instead of lists for the constant arrays to prevent accidental modification.

Group related constants together and separate them with blank lines to improve readability.

title: Update from_csv.py
body:
Add comments to explain the purpose and usage of the code.

Use descriptive variable names to improve code readability.

Use f-strings to format the output message.

title: Update show_chart.py
body:
The code is now wrapped in a main function, which makes it easier to reuse the code and test it.

The main function is now called only if the script is being run directly (i.e., not being imported as a module).

The dataframe variable is now loaded from an external module instead of being defined within the script. This makes the code more modular and easier to read.

The query used to generate the chart is now defined in a separate variable, which makes it easier to modify the query without having to modify the pandas_ai.run call.

title: added google sheets functionality
body:
Hello,
this PR aims at integrating Google Sheets into pandasAI, addressing https://github.com/gventuri/pandas-ai/issues/53 .

I wrote a file where the user sees an example of getting their sheetid and name as inputs, and can enter into into the sheets_input() function to use their sheets dataframe

*used an environment variable for sheet_id as the spreadsheet is public and did not want any changes to be made, however it uses the same gdp data that is already used in the project

title: refine prompt for generic data description
body:
- [ ] closes #28
- [ ] All [code checks passed](https://github.com/gventuri/pandas-ai#contributing).

```
response = pandas_ai.run(df, "what is this data about?")
Running PandasAI with openai LLM...
Code generated:

import pandas as pd
data = {'country': ['Germany', 'United Kingdom', 'Italy', 'France', 'United States'],
        'gdp': [1745433788416, 8168005282, 9078511891, 2508004266, 8484577247],
        'happiness_index': [6.66, 7.07, 6.38, 7.07, 6.38]}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
print(df.head(5))

Answer:           country             gdp  happiness_index
0   United States  19294482071552             6.94
1  United Kingdom   2891615567872             7.16
2          France   2411255037952             6.66
3         Germany   3435817336832             7.07
4           Italy   1745433788416             6.38

```

* with conversational answer:
```
response = pandas_ai.run(df, "what is this data about?", is_conversational_answer=True)
Running PandasAI with openai LLM...
Code generated:

import pandas as pd
data = {'country': ['United Kingdom', 'United States', 'Germany', 'Italy', 'France'],
        'gdp': [1745433788416, 9632157905, 6986361634, 1076747270, 2860360093],
        'happiness_index': [7.07, 6.38, 6.66, 6.38, 6.66]}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
print(df.head(5))

Answer:           country             gdp  happiness_index
0   United States  19294482071552             6.94
1  United Kingdom   2891615567872             7.16
2          France   2411255037952             6.66
3         Germany   3435817336832             7.07
4           Italy   1745433788416             6.38
Conversational answer: This data is about the GDP and happiness index of different countries, including the United States, United Kingdom, France, Germany, and Italy.
```

```
response = pandas_ai.run(df, "describe data?", is_conversational_answer=True)
Running PandasAI with openai LLM...
Code generated:

import pandas as pd
# create dataframe
data = {'country': ['Italy', 'Germany', 'United Kingdom', 'France', 'United States'],
        'gdp': [3435817336832, 5540260089, 4634553596, 1131525958, 6212275854],
        'happiness_index': [7.16, 6.66, 6.38, 6.38, 7.16]}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
# print first 5 rows
print(df.head(5))

Answer:           country             gdp  happiness_index
0   United States  19294482071552             6.94
1  United Kingdom   2891615567872             7.16
2          France   2411255037952             6.66
3         Germany   3435817336832             7.07
4           Italy   1745433788416             6.38
Conversational answer: The data includes information about different countries' GDP and happiness index. It shows the United States has the highest GDP, while the United Kingdom has the highest happiness index among the listed countries. France, Germany, and Italy are also included in the data.
```

title: Allow running with __call__
body:
Hello @gventuri,
this minor PR introduces the simple functionality of running `PandasAI` with the functional operator, e.g.

```py
...
pandas_ai = PandasAI(llm, conversational=False)
result = pandasi(df, prompt)
```

`.run()` is however kept to guarantee retrocompatibilty.

title: chore(deps): make google-palm optional dep
body:
Hi @gventuri, 
this PR aims at addressing #53. 

- [X] closes #153
- [X] All [code checks passed](https://github.com/gventuri/pandas-ai#contributing).

## Changelog:
- google-palm becomes an optional dep, installable via `poetry install --extras google` or `pip install pandasai[google]` or `poetry install --all-extras`. Reference: [poetry documentation](https://python-poetry.org/docs/pyproject/#extras)
- the test workflow installs also the optional dependencies to appropriately run all the tests. A possible alternative would be to instead use `pytest.importskip`, which is the approach adopted in langchain. This would skip the tests of the optional deps. I let you decide what you prefer :)

Charts are saved to `exports/charts/<current date>` with a unique name.

title: fix: remove matplotlib from whitelisted libraries
body:
`matplotlib` is added to the environment passed to `exec()`, it should not also be imported in the run code.
Remove `matplotlib` from `WHITELISTED_LIBRARIES`, so imports are removed from the generated code.
Add ENVIRONMENT_DEFAULTS variable to consolidate logic.

title: feat: unique chart folder names
body:
Use a UUID to generate unique folders for each run of PandasAI to save charts to.
Add the UUID as a prompt id attribute to PandasAI, and open up with an interface in `last_prompt_id()`.
This allows projects built on top of PandasAI to easily retrieve charts generated.
